title: Can we know that we know, all there is to know? - Quora

response.answer_text: Can we know that we know all there is to know? Nice question. We usually say that we do not know all that there is to know. We believe there are things out there that we do not know about - dark energy, extraterrestrials, wormholes, the start of the universe, lots of things. But paraphrasing your question, “can we know, can we be sure, whether there really are things unknown to us?” We could propose that we do know all that there is to know. That would be a hard one to argue against. We can’t really know whether there are unknown things without identifying what they might be, and that’s knowledge. We can select anything we say we don’t know, and propose that it doesn't exist. We can legitimately apply that to all those things mentioned above. Dark energy and wormholes could be fantasies, ET is unprovable, the universe may not have had a beginning. Perhaps I’m just restating it, but every time we say we don’t know something, we are saying we know there to be a something that we don’t know. Perhaps there isn’t.

Apparently. I currently have a particular problem with the word ‘fact’. This is not a word I have really used since I finished my undergraduate degree in Science. That four-year introduction into academia removed most of my resolutions regarding reality. It became evident that ‘evidence’ is the product of examination. This is obviously and necessarily true, but I wonder how many of us really grapple with the concept. As someone who has just spent a day examining people, I am intensely aware of pre-test and post-test probabilities and the unsettling fact that gold standards for diagnosis change. Anyone who doesn’t see the problem with that probably hasn’t thought about it enough…  No standardized guidelines exist for the biostatistical methods appropriate for studies evaluating diagnostic tests. Publication recommendations such as the STARD statement provide guidance for the analysis of data, but biostatistical advice is minimal and application is inconsistent. (Methods and recommendations for evaluating and reporting a new diagnostic test) Can you believe the paragraph above?! The paper I am citing is from a publication of the ESCMID. That body will be one of those responsible for rolling out diagnostic strategies in a pandemic. Which test should we use to determine who is infected? “It’s debatable” is the answer. But tests are what tell us the truth!! Yet data does not tell you how to collect or classify data - especially when you are testing a method of classification. The sooner we get this in our heads, the better. So, you can know all there is to know when you decide that all there is to know is what you know. This is what I find happening on Quora all the time - talk of ‘objective evidence’ and (horror of horrors) ‘scientific fact’. The case is made most obvious in mathematics: one can know with absolute certainty what a result is - however one can know with equal certainty that such a result is not necessarily applicable to any aspect of our experience whatsoever. Show me five ‘fingers’ (one’s a ‘thumb’) and I’ll show you fourteen phalanges. The game is infinite because the boundaries of ‘what is’ are never known except by axiomatic definition.  So, you know you know what there is to know when you can convince yourself of that. It’s that simple and it always has been. It’s how logic produces perfect precision and it’s called a proof. If we avoid asking what the proof pertains to beyond its own assumptions then we will be fine. Some seem able to do this, and (to be honest) I kind of envy them.

A2A: I know not what I don't seek. I seek what I don't know. So I know not what I don't know. I read a few years back, competency goes through four-phases: Unconcious IncompetenceConscious IncompetenceConscious CompetenceUnconscious-CompetenceThe first lacks awareness of what needs to be known. The second is awareness of what needs to be known. The third is awareness that you do know. And the fourth is fluent-awareness that you do know. I believe your question pertains to a phase between the third and fourth-phases listed above. Most would say an all-knowing being is either too advanced on a human-scale or simply doesn't exist. I subscribe to Ayn Rand's line of thought. She suggested we shouldn't complain of our incapacity for omniscience. But to content ourselves with possessing enough contextual-information where survival can take place. We can than improve upon survival, through leveraging that knowledge through tools that save time and effort. I suggest, as Ms. Rand does as well, that we can know enough to get by and improve our lot in life. Yet In short I'd have to say the answer is, no.

I think things are so numerous that most of them will be always unbeknown to us. So I agree there unknown things. But, as a rationalist I think they may remain unknown because they lack necessary interest or import on our reality to arouse our curiosity about them, or because we may reach an end to scientific production for reasons with no business with knowledge itself. Like a worldwide widespread form of religious fanaticism, or a sudden deliberate ecological return to preindustrial forms of life or the very extinction of our species. Most probably, because the realm of knowledge so so immense that we will never manage to have an exaustive account of facts. Other possibility is that there be a king of randomness ingrained in Nature, so future is contingent, so about future events we will ever bump into surprises. What I think is part of the irrational agenda is conceive of such a a theory, never put in the form of scientific method so it could be tested, but always elusive and speculatory, like in MacCollin, Kant, Chomski, is the one that ascertains that there would be things unknowable to us, on account of the limitations on our intellectual capabilities, not because we lack, ad this is a trivial truth that will always the case, not technological means to endorse or falsify whatever theory at the lack of sufficiently powerful instruments or a minimum amount of previous data. Out of principle, nothing in the World can remain out of possible perception and explanation, however minimum their relation being to other entities, it will always manifest in ways we can assess as cause-effects relation of regular nature. Theory is based on this coexistence in a world that follows some structural laws, and thing that do exist, are exposed to inter—influence. Effects of their interaction with the world. We ourselves are no way different. We are conscients incarnated in a body that travels in the world opposite our boundaries as entrapped minds whenever we use our senses or talk or communicate with other minds.

I think we can’t. The problem of this topic is that we are not able to understand or see the things as they ARE, but only a representation of the things accessible to our senses and to our understanding. Hence, all of us have a different (in most of the cases very similar) understanding of the things - say for example if several of us are looking at a cup of tea, most of us will be able to agree on that there is a cup, of color whatever with a brownish -golden liquid in there, etc. However, is this representation describing the thing like it actuall IS? I think not. We are all having a certain level of abstractions in our minds, omitting attributes of details the things (in the tea example nobody would care and see the water molecules comprising the tea liquid, nobody would care about the vibrations of the molecules of the liquid and the cup which we feel as heat, etc.) Hence, depending on the level of abstraction and the level of details you look into phenomena, new things may come up you never could have imagined. It is like Max Planck when he started studying physics at the end of the 19th century: one his Professor adviced him to study something else because “all is known and there is nothing new to discover in the world of physics.” In the end I expect that at some far future, things might converge and the costs of making new discoveries and answering new questions might become so costly and produce such low gain in knowledge that humanity might define the field as closed and as “all that can be known is known”.

Knowing is a cognitive function. That’s the mainstream view. But all of us also know in our hearts, know with our souls. Knowing in this form, reveals knowing’s emotive dimension. Then there’s another kind of knowing, knowing in our spirit, the sense of right or wrong, fairness and unfairness. It can feel like outrage, disappointment, disbelief, existential crises. This kind of knowing has no name, but is nonetheless real once you have experienced it. Some call it conscience, some call it ethical reasoning and morality. No one agrees on its name, but this kind of knowing appears to be universal. In what other ways are we able to know, and able to know that we know? Do we still think it is all cognition? All centred and originating in the brain? The evidence is mounting that we have only just begun to emerge from the brain-centred view of knowing. The Brain-Gut Connection Check out also the endocrine system’s effect on the brain, as well as whether our nervous systems are definitionally separate from the brain. Finally, knowing is filtered through our imperfect memory. There are things that we knew yesterday, but today we no longer. Even collectively.

We can know that we know, but we cannot know-for-sure that we know-for-sure, except our consciousness here and now. Then we can know that we know almost nothing. Even in elementary arithmetic, we can only scratch at the surface, and we are promised (provably so if we assume Mechanism and some amount of self-correctness) an infinity of surprises. The open mind will go from astonishment to astonishment. Yet the doubt will prevail, and a scientist should better say “I believe” or “I assume” than to say “I know”, as only a god could know if our knowledge is a false belief or if it is genuine knowledge (true belief). Compared to arithmetic, when seen from inside, even the physical realm is a thin surface of a far bigger non material (perhaps mathematical) realm.

This is the kind of question I regret not having the time to do justice to. No, no way. In the formal realm, you only have to consider Gödel’s theorems to see that it's impossible to ascertain all that is true. In the realm of reality, we are just a partial configuration thereof, that cannot possibly replicate the totality. That translates into the development of philosophy, which is our response to the ever present—and receding—horizon of the unknown. PS: I dealt with this question indirectly in my book Sense Nonsense, where I say—among other things—that “We can never be sure that there aren’t any unknown unknowns.”

Definitely not and in a different sense definitely yes For example: There are an infinite number of numbers. We cannot know them all. Even if we spent eternity listing all the numbers we currently have symbols for there are infinitely more that we can never express and will never be able to express. Mathematics is a subject with literally no end. It is impossible to discuss without eternal life. And yet God knows everything and so if we ask him he can and sometimes does give us exactly the right answer. You cannot know everything all at the same time and yet God can and if you listen very hard he will tell you the answer you are looking for.

Can we know that we know, all there is to know? I’ve discovered that there isn’t really much to know except the meaning and purpose of human life. The wisdom called Kabbalah is the science of the correct perception of true reality: what it is and how it is manifested. The secrets of the universe are found in this study. Truly. What Is Kabbalah?

The only thing we can know for sure(except for the things we already know), is that there is a lot we don't know. For example, a thousand years ago, no one had even been close(as far as we know) to thinking it possible for us to go to space(it may be that someone thought this, but not as far as I am aware of. It’s just for the sake of the argument.). Up until the moment someone thought this, the possibility did not exist. We were not able to concieve this all the way up to the point where someone thought it. I have a hard time giving a good explanation of this, but I know very well that in a thousand years from now, we have made discoveries and had ideas that we have yet to think of as a species. Therefore, based on the history of knowledge that we have, we will know things in the future, of which we are yet to concieve.

Not in our current state. In order to get all of the answers that we need we need to rise our levels of consciousness. This world we find ourselves in is a world of consequences, nothing more. In order to get all the answers we need, we need to raise our level of perception and break into the spiritual reality that governs all of our lives and everything that happens on the level of this world.  Until The Worm Grows Into A Human Being | Laitman.com

Due to the limitations we humans have in observing (our extremely limited perspective), we can never know more than a very thin veneer on the surface of any one truth. But still, there are a very large number of layers of veneer covering all aspects of truth, so there are and will always be “closer to truth”. So knowing everything is even more impossible. Here’s some data to put impossible of “knowing all” into perspective and this is just the physical world, not the spiritual world:

I agree with Bruno Marchal below. I am not a professional mathematician or physicist, but, I do know through reading and videos that for example some constraints on knowledge are placed on us by nature itself, such as Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle, which we know to be true. We can know the probable location of particles, but if we try to deeply know what are called the position and momentum of a particle, it is impossible because of how Nature itself is constructed.

I KNOW for a fact we can’t. We have yet to explore all that God created. We have yet learned tolerance for those who look and sound different. We have not mastered the art of communication for its still being used to spread hatred. We have not achieved the banishment of hunger, cruelty, prejudice, towards each other but especially towards children and animals. No, we are a self absorbed creation **Note .According to government estimates, around two million people spend time homeless in America every year. Among them are women with children, victims of violence, people with serious mental illnesses, drug addicts, alcoholics, and those who simply can't afford to pay their rent. Millions more don't have enough money to pay for their food as well as their utility bills, such as electricity or gas. They may use soup kitchens for meals. They many also visit a food pantry which distributes basic foodstuffs such as bread, milk, and dried and tinned goods. Linda Donaldson is the director of advocacy and family services at SOME:
No.

We don’t need to know all there is to know. You can’t eat all the food at the buffet at once or you’ll be sick and overwhelmed. You can know all you need to know at the time and trust the rest will come to you when you need it. That is all.

Yes we can know what all there is to know. But to know this one has to understand what is knowing. When knowing is understood then what is known and who is knowing all are understood. This knowing is that which can know all we can know.

No. That would be like God, super loving Mastermind. The problem is many 1/ don't know they don't know yet they are aggressive - of pride, hubris or arrogance - 2/ don't know they know - insecurity but 3/ the need is to know that you know what you can know, limited but key knowledge.

The universe is a functioning machine with a complex algorithm which I think philosophically is a dialectical materialism. That philosophy prevents us from knowing everything that there’s to know because it can come up with something contrary to what we know to be true.

What we need to know is more fundamental than knowing everything[ or trying to comprehend all the knowledge that is available]. First we must know who we are. I am spirit soul encaged in a body and this body would go through diseases, distress, old age, and then death. I don’t want these things but they are imposed upon me by a higher force. How can I stop these maladies, surrender to that higher force, God [Krishna]. But how? Approach a bonafide Guru and he will enlighten you how to become self realized and God realized. This is spiritual knowledge. Material knowledge is essential for you to get by in this world but it is secondary to spiritual knowledge.

Learning and discovery and self-cultivation constitute a continuing process. We never know all there is to know - who would want to do that? Each moment is a new situation. What we can continue to discover is ourselves.

Nope, humans aren’t created that way. That’s why we are so different in many ways. We are designed to teach and learn from each other through interactions and communication with each other. Every contact with eachother, we learn something different and new.

No. (1) How could we know for sure? (2) My OPINION is that our brains haven’t evolved enough to truly understand the entirety of this amazing and wonderful Universe. (3) Can a mind really understand itself?
There is want to know and need to know. Want to know often begets progress and need to know instills safety. I could know more later if I want to know although right now I have enough need to know.

There are known knowns - Wikipedia there are things we know and thing we know that we don’t know and there are things we don’t know that we don’t know. So then are there thing we don’t know that we know?
Never. Only God has all knowledge.
I dunno?!
Yes
